title: Question 38

children: A 28-year-old man is hospitalized for cough, headaches, nausea, and vomiting of 1 week's duration. Two days ago, he developed a stiff neck. He has otherwise been well and takes no medications.

On physical examination, temperature is 38 °C (100.4 °F), blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, pulse rate is 112/min, and respiration rate is 22/min. Nuchal rigidity is present; neurologic examination is normal. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly.

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

Cryptococcal infection most often occurs in immunocompromised persons, such as those with HIV, solid organ transplant or stem cell transplant recipients, those taking glucocorticoids, or those with diabetes mellitus. However, cryptococcal infection can also occur in otherwise healthy persons. The central nervous system is the most common site of infection. CSF findings include an increased leukocyte count (mainly lymphocytes), an increased protein level, a low to normal glucose level, and the presence of cryptococcal antigen. Serum cryptococcal antigen is positive in greater than 95% of infected patients. Because the mortality rate is more than 50% in healthy patients, combination antifungal therapy should be initiated immediately. After successful induction therapy with amphotericin B and flucytosine, consolidation therapy with fluconazole can be initiated. Many symptoms of increased intracranial pressure may be improved by CSF removal through daily lumbar puncture or insertion of a shunt. Aggressive reduction of intracranial pressure reduces early morbidity and mortality.
